Dateline 1-24-2018 Persistent demand around the $10,000 mark appears to have not only neutralized the immediate bearish outlook on bitcoin, but also hints the cryptocurrency could be building a base for an eventual move higher. Prices on CoinDesk's Bitcoin Price Index (BPI) fell to $9,972.29 yesterday, before witnessing a quick recovery to $11,000 levels. This is the fourth time in last week that bitcoin (BTC) has recovered losses after sinking below $10,000 levels. As of writing, bitcoin is at $10,990 levels. The cryptocurrency has appreciated by 3.38 percent in the last 24 hours, according to data source OnChainFX. On Coinbase's GDAX exchange, BTC witnessed two-way business yesterday with prices hitting highs and lows of $$11, 370 and $9,945, respectively, before closing (as per UTC) at $10,824 levels. The situation looks no different today as the rebound from the intraday low of $10,450 seems to have run out of steam above $11,000 levels. The cryptocurrency was last seen changing hands on GDAX at $10,970 levels. The two-way price action witnessed in the last 24 hours is indicative of indecision in the marketplace and a decisive move (in either direction) would likely set the tone for the market. That said, the price chart analysis today puts the odds of a decisive move higher above 50 percent. -- https://www.coindesk.com/building-a-base-bitcoin-demand-at-10k-hints-at-move-higher/

With a daily vol of 5.1% and annualized vol of 80% of price change on bitcoin I see it as a high probability it will close above $10K with only three trading days left. I'm thinking about this more and I feel like $10k might carry some bizarre psychological weight. People will think "deal!" if they see it below $10k and jump in, pushing the price back up over the short-term. It doesn't matter that not too long ago the price was below $10k, just that there is a line of people with a case of FOMO.

Bitcoin has been extremely volatile lately. Over the past three months bitcoin has traded at a low $5,600 to a high of $19,500.  With no true basis of economic return to assess (i.e. cash flows), it is fairly impossible to predict its price. It's price is based on supply and demand, which is largely speculative at this point. I am adjusting my forecast lower than I previously thought. The price can conceivably be at any level. There is no reason to say it can't be at $4,000 or $500,000. I am adjusting it to 50/50 of between $7000-10,000 and "more than $10,000".

Few reasons I'm increasing the likelihoods of the lower brackets:
1. Obviously today's BTC/USD price drop has been spectacular. Similar to what we saw from 18-22 December last year. Possible that this is the first day of the "fire sale" and similarly to mid-December more such down days are to follow.
2. BTC regulation related woes are continuing. France and Germany are now calling for BTC regulation, ROK is still working on how to ban crypto currency markets and China's central bank looks to tighten ban on crypto currency trade.

Crypto will have a place in society going forward.  Many people think it will be the next beanie baby, and many others think it will keep going up. The truth is far less dramatic.  Value in Bitcoin will fade all year, one of the most prominent reason, is the proliferation of so many cryptocurrencies.  Bitcoin also has structural problems and it is very hard to use in real life.  That will be resolved in the long term, but building out the infrastructure will take time.  Bitcoin with have a long downtrend over 18.

Twelve days to go and the overall trend is downward. Churn still is spectacularly high. For example, from 8AM to 9AM MST today, ~ 3 million Bitcoins changed hands amid a drop in price bottoming out at ~$12,870. Those three million Bitcoins represent ~ one fifth of all Bitcoins in existence.  I still cannot imagine how the price isn't more volatile, given the lack of underlying value  and the churn rate.  The only reason I am giving such a high probability to >$10K is that the behavior of the overall system bespeaks some sort of collusion to keep the little guys in the game -- AKA marks, AKA suckers, the guys who read make money fast in Bitcoin ads in the airline magazines. The basic problem facing Bitcoin users is that many of them are using it to launder money. The big problem overall is how to convert Bitcoin into fiat money, meaning currencies backed by governments. Right now, billions of USD equivalent dollars are being churned and some of it is being extracted permanently rather than reinvested, day trader style. That I believe is a good hypothesis given the churn rate. But the only way to permanently extract laundered money from the Bitcoin system is to have new  investors/marks/suckers stepping up[ to buy when prices fall. Therefore it is important for the big guys (AKA whales AKA organized crime AKA kleptocratic world leaders and their hangers on) to keep the suckers from spooking. That means not being greedy, feeding money back into the system  as needed, perhaps with some encrypted communications to determines who steps up to the plate when. If I am wrong, sometime soon, maybe before the forecast horizon, the whales will let Bitcoin collapse below $10K. They may let it collapse because they already have extracted all they need . It may be that  whenever the price falls too fast, it now is the suckers en mass who rush in with bargain buying, what a deal!!!  If the price is now mostly being stabilized by the suckers, here is what I know about small time day traders. They typically are male and typically think they are geniuses. They buy in the morning and cash out all their positions by bed time. Or vice versa if unemployed and with a modest inheritance to gamble. But the problem with Bitcoin day traders is that, compared with stocks, it costs more on average to buy and sell and it takes longer for a trade to sell Bitcoins to result in money in the bank. So this increases the danger that Mom or The Wife may discover a big savings deficit and put an end to it. So this legion of females is a wildcard that I can't forecast.

Beware the bears! The little guys (many of whom read those airline magazine ads for Bitcoin sales) are piling in expecting it to rise, while the big guys are shorting it. Whales might be the exception to the big guys because I don't know who they are. The little guys who bought early and are simply holding their coins (hodlers)  are  also betting Bitcoin will rise, but unlike the newbie small investors, they have an almost religious belief that in the long run, Bitcoin always will go up. Adding to the difficulty of forecasting Bitcoin, the very secrecy that is its prime feature enables collusion ans=d server money launderers. How to money launderers extract their stashes from Bitcoin? They need marks, little guys whom they must be careful not to spook with overly fast extraction of their wealth. Right now, Bitcoin is $16,420 with some episodes of heavy trading, for example ~3M/hr around 10AM MST today, out of the ~16M in circulation. Normally this high churn rate would predict high volatility and high likelihood of a crash below $10K. So my only explanation s a combination of collusion by the big guys along with a plethora of small investors who can be fleeced if the big guys can be patient. So I'm going slightly over the consensus here. Dateline 1-7-2018  Small investors are betting that bitcoin’s price will rise, while hedge funds and other large traders are betting it will fall. That is the pattern rapidly emerging after four weeks of trading in the first U.S. bitcoin futures market, launched last month by Cboe Global Markets Inc. Futures are a type of contract that enables traders to wager whether the future price of an underlying asset will rise or fall. -- https://www.wsj.com/articles/little-guys-and-big-trading-firms-square-off-in-bitcoin-futures-arena-1515326400

The exuberance seems strong enough to carry on as long as overall economic conditions provide people with disposable wealth.  Any kind of economic shocks could also have a temporary and unexpected effect of driving up the price of Bitcoin. For some examples, think of the panic "logic" driving any Zerohedge forecast of impending hyperinflation, stock market collapse, etc. Imagine people thinking about how if they had all their money in Bitcoin they would have weathered a stock market crash. Maybe Jeff Sessions cracking down on legal weed might drive people online for their purchases. That could help float the interest in Bitcoin longer, but it doesn't seem to be enough to prop up the price since Bitcoin isn't just a US market.  With the introduction of futures exchanges and big banks getting in on the action, drastic action (another potential shock) by the American government seems less likely. It also makes it easier to gamble on Bitcoin. The only legitimate function still seems to be for people fleeing oppressive regimes to convert their wealth, or for people sheltering assets in less developed nations.  Then there's the off-chance Bitcoin sticks around because enough people take the "leap of faith" and never abandon it.

BTC appears to remain resilient to news on other cryptocurrencies, the Israeli regulators' trade ban movement, South Korea's bans and other developments. Also CBOE futures trading appears to have slightly brought down volatility. While any development may well lead to violent moves in the price, there is little to indicate a forthcoming collapse (today's price = $16336)

Dateline 12-8-2017 On Nov. 12, someone moved almost 25,000 bitcoins, worth about $159 million at the time, to an online exchange. The news soon rippled through online forums, with bitcoin traders arguing about whether it meant the owner was about to sell the digital currency.
Holders of large amounts of bitcoin are often known as whales. And they’re becoming a worry for investors. They can send prices plummeting by selling even a portion of their holdings. And those sales are more probable now that the cryptocurrency is up nearly twelvefold from the beginning of the year.
About 40 percent of bitcoin is held by perhaps 1,000 users; at current prices, each may want to sell about half of his or her holdings, says Aaron Brown, former managing director and head of financial markets research at AQR Capital Management. (Brown is a contributor to the Bloomberg Prophets online column.) What’s more, the whales can coordinate their moves or preview them to a select few. Many of the large owners have known one another for years and stuck by bitcoin through the early days when it was derided, and they can potentially band together to tank or prop up the market.
“I think there are a few hundred guys,” says Kyle Samani, managing partner at Multicoin Capital. “They all probably can call each other, and they probably have.” One reason to think so: At least some kinds of information sharing are legal, says Gary Ross, a securities lawyer at Ross & Shulga. Because bitcoin is a digital currency and not a security, he says, there’s no prohibition against a trade in which a group agrees to buy enough to push the price up and then cashes out in minutes. -- https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-08/the-bitcoin-whales-1-000-people-who-own-40-percent-of-the-market

I thought back-of-the-envelope that to serve that function, the 21M BTC that will ultimately be in circulation would be worth about $400K each ($8T/21M). So if it reaches 20% of that, we're at an $80K BTC. Of course, it may only do some fraction of that as well. I have been considering an interesting paper that looks at stock bubbles, from NBER: http://www.nber.org/papers/w23191.pdf Which I learned of through a pessimistic article in Market Watch: https://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-chance-of-a-bitcoin-crash-is-greater-than-80-2017-11-27 This research is a persuasive argument that a 40% price drop occurs within two years for 80% assets that see a greater than 100% increase in a short time period (I'm not clear on the time period, but evidently BTC has been a record-setting increase so surely qualifies). So why bet against this analysis? My own inclination for the evaluation of BTC is that it actually already had its speculative bubble burst -- in late 2013 BTC made a run that saw its price rise about 10X, then fall about 40% (as this paper predicts). To me, BTC surviving this event and now being adopted by institutions, getting serious attention from regulators, beginning to penetrate the awareness of retail investors, etc. This isn't to say there couldn't be more than one bubble for a single asset class -- oil has had many bubbles and shocks -- but my guess is that the recent rise reflects more of an understanding of the fundamental value of BTC in helping preserve people's wealth, better documenting ownership, the potential to reduce fees and be more portable, cross borders etc. Benefits that have yet to be realised overall, but which are very promising. Looking out further than this, still more factors come into play, but for Jan 26, 2018, I suspect BTC is more likely to continue its climb.

Still, the biggest impacts on the price continue to be largely event-related. ETH and BTC volatilities have become more similar recently, which is of note - we take that as a sign of growing acceptance of blockchain, if not outright stability, and of healthy competition that likely would only be shaken by large-scale adoption of one or the other currency.  BTC fork-related currencies, with all the debate swirling around each one, have, overall, seemed to struggle to make a clear impact in their parent currency's valuation; and it seems like even a successful offshoot might find it difficult to dilute the popularity of BTC short of a large company or government legitimizing it.

2 important pieces of news.  1)  a programming change which would have doubled the number of transactions possible but also might have caused many "true believers" to leave Bitcoin, has been cancelled.  2)  If I was a billionaire Saudi prince spending time on an unplanned visit to a 5* hotel, I'd be moving as much money into Bitcoin as I could, ASAP! https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/08/technology/bitcoin-expansion-called-off.html?emc=edit_th_20171109&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=77825025 A long-running civil war over the design of Bitcoin appears to be over for now, after one side in the fight acknowledged on Wednesday that it had not won sufficient support from other virtual currency backers. The camp that conceded had been hoping to double the number of transactions that could be run through the network that supports Bitcoin, in order to keep transactions cheap and fast.
This expansion was vociferously opposed by many of the programmers working on the Bitcoin project, who worried that expanding the network quickly would make it easier for a company or government to exert influence over the decentralized system. The group pushing for expansion had planned to switch to a new version of the Bitcoin software next week, which would have created a split in the network and most likely wreaked havoc on the virtual currency. This planned split, though, was called off on Wednesday, after the companies proposing it failed to win significant support from the Bitcoin community. In an email, the leaders of several of the largest Bitcoin companies said that “unfortunately, it is clear that we have not built sufficient consensus for a clean block size upgrade at this time.” The price of Bitcoin shot up immediately after the email went out, hitting a new high, above $7,800, before retreating. The price has been steadily climbing and is up nearly 1,000 percent over the last year. The rising price has attracted many new users, from places like Japan and South Korea and from big hedge funds, even as the authorities in places like China have cracked down on the currency. All of the new people seeking access to Bitcoin have run up against a limit on the number of transactions that can flow through the system every 10 minutes, which was put in place during Bitcoin’s early years. Because of the limit, the network can process only around five transactions a second. That has led to delays on the network and has pushed up the price of getting a Bitcoin transaction through. Companies that help process Bitcoin payments have been pushing to lift the limit on Bitcoin transactions for several years, arguing that it will be necessary if Bitcoin wants to compete with Visa or PayPal. The opposing camp has argued that quickly expanding the number of transactions flowing through the network would mean only large companies could track Bitcoin transactions, taking power away from individual users. The proponents of keeping the so-called blocks of Bitcoin transactions small said Bitcoin should be viewed more as digital gold: a secure place to keep money, even if it can’t be moved around as quickly and cheaply. Many of the programmers working on the basic Bitcoin software — the so-called core developers — said they would stop working on Bitcoin if the block size was increased. They also complained that the companies pushing through the block size increase were doing so without properly consulting the community. Leaders on both sides of the Bitcoin debate have complained about receiving death threats and hacking attacks, and some top developers have migrated toward other virtual currencies. In August, some of the most outspoken proponents of expanding Bitcoin created their own version, known as Bitcoin Cash, which can handle more transactions than traditional Bitcoin. The price of Bitcoin Cash has gone up since August, but it remains only a small fraction of the size of Bitcoin. On Wednesday, the companies that had been pushing for big blocks said they were calling off their plans in order to restore some measure of peace to the community. “Although we strongly believe in the need for a larger block size, there is something we believe is even more important: keeping the community together,” the email said. The announcement said that the companies still believed that an increase in the size of Bitcoin blocks would be necessary, but that they were willing to wait until the community agreed on a way to deal with the issue. The people opposed to quickly expanding the network say they still wanted to make it easier and cheaper to use Bitcoin. But they hope this will be made possible by new networks built on top of Bitcoin, keeping the Bitcoin network itself more secure and decentralized.

Haven't seen anyone post the numbers that finance would give you, so thought I'd share. Bitcoin Price (10/30/2017):  $6,075
Daily Trading Volatility: (~4.2%)
Trading Days: 365 (Remember, unlike stocks / bonds Bitcoin is valued every day) Annualized Volatility = Daily Volatility * sqrt (Trading Days) = 4.2% * sqrt ( 365) = 79.8% Period Volatility = Annual Volatility * Sqrt (Days in Period / 365) = 47% For those that are not familiar with volatility:  
"Typical" annual stock volatility is roughly 20%.  So Bitcoin is nearly 4 times as volatile as the typical stock.   Before we can convert volatility into probability we need to have an estimate with what the average return investors expect to take on this astronomical amount of risk.  Now according to Finance (Black-Scholes option pricing model), this would be the "risk-free rate" over that duration Black-Scholes Midpoint: $6,111 However, Black-Scholes assumes that pricing is rational in an arbitrage free world. I highly suspect that bitcoin pricing violates both of these axioms.  As such, I've moved the midpoint up considerably to adjust for the abnormal environment in which Bit Coin trades.  Said differently, if investors don't see a huge return on their investment immediately (even though they shouldn't expect this), volatility is likely to increase further.   mwokasch Adjusted Midpoint: $6,475
Note:  My midpoint adjustment makes virtually no difference amid such wild volatility, It's impact is essentially moving 4% from the top bracket to the bottom two brackets.  Applying the normal-distribution curve on top of a Midpoint of $6,475, annual standard deviation of 79.8% results in my forecast probabilities. I based my forecast on the fact that the btc is around 6k usd right now. I looked at the risk, the past prices and guessed the following.

The starting point for the forecast is looking at how much Bitcoin's price had grown (or contracted) 3 months after a point in time. I looked at a year of daily closing prices starting on 29 July 2016. This gave a possible increase in price by 26 January 2018 ranging from c.5% to c.197% on the basis of historic performance alone and formed the baseline for the forecast.
The baseline was then modified to reflect a range of analyst opinions backing outcomes from Bitcoin collapse to a surge in growth.
